results.title: An Interview with Joyce Bryan
results.brief_description: Joyce Bryan was a witness to the return of the Prisoners of War from Japan. She provides an powerful and detailed rendering of the emotionally charged return and the struggles of the men to fit back into society.
results.description: Joyce Bryan was a witness to the return of the Prisoners of War from Japan. She provides an powerful and detailed rendering of the emotionally charged return and the struggles of the men to fit back into society.

results.title: An Interview with John Balloch
results.brief_description: John Balloch was at school when war was declared. Even so, he couldn’t wait to sign up. He wanted to be a fighter pilot, flying alone. He tells of his training and time serving in the RAAF during World War II and pays tribute to those lost, both to the enemy and accidents.

results.title: An Interview with Jock McAuley
results.creator_credit: Jock McAuley and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Jock McAuley remembers hearing Prime Minister Menzies announcing Australia was at war. He was only 15 or 16 at the time and wondered if the would be still going by the time he was old enough to join. Against his dad’s wishes, Jock joined up and served as a pilot during the war. He tells of his experiences fighting for Australia.

He tells of his experiences fighting for Australia.

results.title: An Interview with Jim Dickson
results.brief_description: Commodore Jim Dickson came from a Naval family and joined the cadets at 13. As a ship navigator off the coast of Vietnam in 1965, he experienced the pressure of being responsible for the welfare of the crew and the ship. He reflects on the turbulence of the era, the bonds that are formed in times of adversity and the terrible waste wrought by war.

results.title: An Interview with Jessie Perkins
results.brief_description: Jessie Perkins was 16 when World War II started. When she was 18, Japan entered the war and Jessie was keen to contribute, but her dad wouldn’t let her. She tells of how her convinced her father to let her go, her time at the Australian Army Service Corp in Geelong and, ultimately, her long and distinguished career in the army.

She tells of how her convinced her father to let her go, her time at the Australian Army Service Corp in Geelong and, ultimately, her long and distinguished career in the army.

results.title: An Interview with Jan McCarthy
results.brief_description: Jan McCarthy traces her career path of nursing, how it took her overseas and her time in the army, posted in Vietnam and Singapore. In Singapore, McCarthy became a Major and was later promoted to Colonel. She has no regrets about serving in the army and sees it as one big family.
results.description: Jan McCarthy traces her career path of nursing, how it took her overseas and her time in the army, posted in Vietnam and Singapore. results.title: An Interview with James Ross Irvine
results.brief_description: James Ross Irvine and his brother were both involved in significant battles in Papua New Guinea in World War II. With a stoic sensibility and grim humour, Irvine relates the story of the last time he saw his brother before he was killed in battle.

results.title: An Interview with Jack Jones
results.brief_description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.
results.description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.

results.title: An Interview with Harry Barkla
results.brief_description: Harry Barkla was part of the 39th Battalion, made up mostly of Chocolate (Chocco) soldiers. They were called this because it was thought that they would melt in the sun, that they wouldn’t know how to fight. In Kokoda, they soon proved themselves and Harry talks about some of the horrific experiences he went through that were typical of this war. These are some of his memories that he has tried to forget but never can. Even if you didn’t know someone’s name in the 39th Battalion, you still called them mate and you never forget your mates.
results.description: Harry Barkla was part of the 39th Battalion, made up mostly of Chocolate (Chocco) soldiers. results.title: An Interview with Harold Brown
results.brief_description: Harold Brown reflects fondly on his time in the army. Joining the artillery division in 1942, he was posted to Bougainville, where disease was more of a threat to the soldiers than the Japanese. Despite longing to be back home with his newborn son, Brown could not have wished to be with a better crew.
results.description: Harold Brown reflects fondly on his time in the army. Despite longing to be back home with his newborn son, Brown could not have wished to be with a better crew.
